content: {{knowledge objective |Identifiant=OIC-049-10-A |Item_parent=Normal and pathological puberty |Item_parent_short=Normal and pathological puberty |Rank=A |Title=Knowing the data from the interview and clinical examination pointing to precocious puberty |Description=None |Rubric=Positive diagnosis |Contributors= |Order=10}} '''Questioning data:''' pubertal ages of parents and siblings, age at menarche of mother, parental heights with calculation of genetic target height, family or personal history (IUGR, neurological history, adoption, neurofibromatosis type 1 (NF1)), visual signs or signs of HTIC (headache, nausea, morning vomiting), analysis of growth rate (curve). Clinical examination: Complete examination, pubertal stage (Tanner), skin spots, signs of hyperandrogenism (acne, hirsutism, hyperseborrhoea, clitoral hypertrophy).

question.title: What is the most likely indication for a clinical examination in a patient with precocious puberty?
question.description: A patient presents with signs of precocious puberty. What is the most likely indication for a clinical examination?

option_a.title: Family history of a genetic disorder
option_a.description: A family history of a genetic disorder such as neurofibromatosis type 1 (NF1) may be a indication for a clinical examination.

option_b.title: Visual signs of hyperandrogenism
option_b.description: Visual signs of hyperandrogenism such as acne, hirsutism, and clitoral hypertrophy may be a indication for a clinical examination.

option_c.title: Analysis of growth rate
option_c.description: Analysis of growth rate may be a indication for a clinical examination, but it is not the most likely indication.

option_d.title: Pubertal ages of parents and siblings
option_d.description: Pubertal ages of parents and siblings may be a indication for a clinical examination, but it is not the most likely indication.
